Major subfields of linguistics:<br><br>
- **Phonetics** – physical attributes of speech sounds<br><br>
- **Phonology** – speech sounds considered as a system<br><br>
- **Morphology** – structure of words<br><br>
- **Syntax** – structure of sentences<br><br>
- **Semantics** – literal meaning<br><br>
- **Pragmatics** – implied meaning
]

##**Review of Terms for Different Morphemes**
<br><br>
.pull-left[
- <b>root</b> (base; **build**, **flower**)<br><br>
- <b>affix</b> (morpheme that attaches to the base)<br><br>
  - <b>prefix</b> (**un**-do)<br><br>
  - <b>suffix</b> (walk-**ed**)<br><br>
  - <b>infix</b> (rare in English)<br><br>
  - <b>circumfix</b> (**em**-bold-**en**)<br><br>
- <b>free vs. bound morpheme</b>
  - can appear as an independent word?
  - **blue**berry vs. **cran**berry<br><br>
]
.pull-right[
- <b>derivational morpheme</b> (piano --> pian-**ist**) 
  - change core meaning even part of speech<br><br>
- <b>inflectional morpheme</b> (jump --> jump-**ed**) 
  - add some grammatical nuance<br><br>
- <b>homophone</b> (fast-**er**, teach-**er**)
  - same sound, different meanings<br><br>
- <b>allomorph</b> (**magic**, **magic**-ian)
  - same meaning, different sounds<br><br>
- <b>simple word vs. compound word</b>
  - one root = simple (inter-**nation**-al)
  - more than one = compound (**sawhorse**)
]

## **Morphological Analysis**
<br><br>
- **Morphological analysis** is a technique for figuring out how the morphology of a language works.<br><br>
- You can use it to learn how the morphology of an unfamiliar language works – as long as you have a set of words with different morphemes and their translations (**glosses**) into English. <br><br>
- **Steps**:
  1. Identify any **repeated** sequences of sounds in the dataset – they may be morphemes.<br><br>
  2. Identify any **repeated** meanings in the English glosses.<br><br>
  3. Try to match each meaning from Step 2 with a potential morpheme from Step 1. (Try to find two words that differ by just one meaning or morpheme.)<br><br>

- **Notes**: As you go, look out for any potential **homophones** or **allomorphs**, and don’t be afraid to **revise your hypotheses** if the data suggests you’re on the wrong track.
